Pilocarpine is a drug used to treat dry mouth and glaucoma. It is a parasympathomimetic alkaloid obtained from the leaves of tropical South American shrubs from the genus Pilocarpus. Pilocarpine is used to stimulate sweat glands in a sweat test to measure the concentration of chloride and sodium that is excreted in sweat. It is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis.

How to use pilocarpine. Take this medication by mouth with or without food, usually 3-4 times daily, or as directed by your doctor. To reduce your risk of side effects, your doctor may direct you to start this medication at a low dose and gradually increase your dose. Follow your doctor's instructions carefully.

Pharmacologic Classification: Cholinergic. Uses For pilocarpine. Pilocarpine tablets are used to treat dryness of the mouth and throat caused by a decrease in the amount of saliva that may occur after radiation treatment for cancer of the head and neck or in patients with Sjogren's syndrome.

Pilocarpine affects the nervous system and increases saliva secretion in the mouth. Pilocarpine is used to treat dry mouth caused by Sjogren's syndrome, or by radiation to treat head and neck cancer. Pilocarpine may also be used for purposes not listed in this medication guide. You should not use pilocarpine if you have narrow-angle glaucoma, or asthma that is untreated or uncontrolled.
